review.title: Big IoT and social networking data for smart cities: Algorithmic improvements on Big Data Analysis in the context of RADICAL city applications
review.abstract: In this paper we present a SOA (Service Oriented Architecture)-based platform, enabling the retrieval and analysis of big datasets stemming from social networking (SN) sites and Internet of Things (IoT) devices, collected by smart city applications and socially-aware data aggregation services. A large set of city applications in the areas of Participating Urbanism, Augmented Reality and Sound-Mapping throughout participating cities is being applied, resulting into produced sets of millions of user-generated events and online SN reports fed into the RADICAL platform. Moreover, we study the application of data analytics such as sentiment analysis to the combined IoT and SN data saved into an SQL database, further investigating algorithmic and configurations to minimize delays in dataset processing and results retrieval.

metadata.title: BIG IOT AND SOCIAL NETWORKING DATA FOR SMART CITIES: Algorithmic improvements on Big Data Analysis in the context of RADICAL city applications

sections.text: Analysis of large datasets sourced from social networking sites (SN) and the Internet of Things (IoT) and collected by smart city applications and socially aware data aggregation services. In the areas of participating urbanism, augmented reality and sound mapping, a large number of city applications are currently in use in participating cities, resulting in millions of user-generated events and online SN reports being fed into the RADICAL platform. In addition, we investigate the application of data analytics such as mood analysis to the combined IoT and SN data stored in an SQL database, and explore other algorithms and configurations to minimize delays in processing and retrieval of data sets.

sections.heading: 1 INTRODUCTION
sections.text: Modern cities are increasingly turning to ICT technology to cope with the pressures of demographic change, urbanization, smart emissions, climate change (Romero Lankao, 2008) and globalization. Therefore, most cities have made significant investments in ICT infrastructure over the past decade, including computers, broadband connectivity and recently detected infrastructures. However, these infrastructures have enabled a range of innovative services in areas such as participatory sensors, urban logistics and ambient assisted living. Such services have been widely deployed in several cities, demonstrating the potential benefits of ICT infrastructure for businesses and citizens themselves. sections.heading: 4.1 Introduction
sections.text: The term sentiment analysis refers to an automatic classification problem. Its techniques attempt to distinguish between sentences of natural language that convey positive (e.g. happiness, pride, joy), negative (e.g. anger, sadness, jealousy) or even neutral (no-sentiment texts such as statements, messages, reports) emotions (designated as sentiment for our purposes) (Pang et al., 2002).A human being is capable of understanding a wide variety of emotions from textual data.This understanding process is based on complicated learning processes that we all go through while using our language as a means of communication, whether active or passive. It requires imagination and subjectivity to fully understand the meaning and hidden connections of each word in a sentence, two things that machines do not process.The most common practice is to extract numerical features from natural language (Godbole et al., 2007). This process translates this complex means of communication into something that machines can process.

sections.heading: 4.3 Dataset Improvements
sections.text: At the heart of sentiment analysis is the data set. We are collecting and using ever larger sets of data to better train algorithms to distinguish what is positive from what is negative. Traditional storage techniques are increasingly cumbersome for large sets of data. ArrayLists and most collections add a large amount of overhead to the data, not only increasing the space needed to store it, but also delaying the analysis process. Therefore, new techniques for data storage and recovery are needed, techniques that allow us to store even larger sets of data and access them with even smaller delays. The most commonly used such technique is the hash list (Fan and Khademi, 2014), which first hacks the data in a certain predefined amount of buckets and then creates a list in each bucket to resolve any collisions.

sections.heading: 4.4 Results
sections.text: We measured three main KPIs for comparison of results: Two of them (success rate, kappa variable) measured the success ratio of the classification and one (execution time) measured the algorithmic improvement. We present them below. We perform experiments with 5 grams in the classic ArrayList format, in hash lists and in Dimensional Mapping. After storing the N-grams in these formats, we applied a 10-fold cross-validation to each of the seven machine learning algorithms we selected: naive Bayesian networks, C4.5, support vector machines, logistic regression, multilayer perctrons, best-first trees and functional trees. sections.heading: 5. CONCLUSIONS
sections.text: The RADICAL platform, as presented in the current paper, successfully combines input from citizens accessed via smartphone applications and social networks in the context of smart city applications to create a test bed for the application of multiple analytical functionalities and techniques; the use of the resulting large aggregated datasets poses several challenges, the most important of which is timely efficient analysis; with a focus on data storage and representation, the experiments explored several techniques to find the optimal algorithmic approach to dimensional mapping; and in the future, the authors plan to use even larger and more complex datasets to further exploit the effectiveness of these social networking services.
